Okay, honest take:

## What's Working

**The core insight is sound.** AI coding is chaotic — it forgets what it built, loses track of decisions, can't explain its own architecture. You're building the missing control system. That's real.

**The architecture is clean.** 10k lines, 3 sessions, 32 items shipped. The Hono + React + file-based store stack is simple and it works. The scanner can infer structure from any codebase. The graph visualizer went from idea to working in one session. You're building fast.

**The data model is the product.** The backlog/issues/ideas/brain structure is elegant. It's generic enough to work for any project but opinionated enough to be useful. The file format *could* become a standard — that's not marketing, that's architecture.

## What's Fragile

**It's not solving its own problem yet.** You built a tool to track AI work... but the AI building it *still* forgot to update the changelog. That's the meta-issue. ISS-006 is existential: if the tool can't enforce its own tracking during its own development, why would it work for anyone else?

**The UI is functional but not compelling.** You noticed the graph was confusing. The views work but they're not beautiful. For a tool that's supposed to make complexity understandable, the UX needs to be *obviously* better than raw files. Right now it's "better" but not "wow."

**The AI chat agent is half-built and critical.** You're building a chat-first architecture but the chat doesn't work yet. That's the real interface. Everything else is just views on data. If the chat isn't magical, the tool is just a prettier JSON editor.

## Direction Thoughts

### Near-term (next 2 weeks)
1. **Finish the AI chat agent.** Get API keys working, test real conversations, make tool calls render beautifully. This is the soul of the product.
2. **Fix ISS-006 with a background watcher (IDEA-014).** If you can't solve "AI forgets to track" in your own dogfooding, the tool has no credibility. The watcher that auto-updates changelog from git diffs is the right architecture.
3. **Use it on Pillar for one real session.** The ultimate validation is: does it actually help you build Pillar faster?

### Medium-term (1-2 months)
4. **UI overhaul (IDEA-011).** Cursor-inspired minimalism. Make it *feel* like a professional tool. You'll notice ugly things — fix them before anyone else sees it.
5. **Living wiki (IDEA-016).** The Docs tab should be a self-updating knowledge base. That's your onboarding story: "install dev-track, it reads your codebase, generates docs, and now any AI can understand your project."
6. **Distribution model (IDEA-021).** Local daemon + web platform hybrid. This is the right architecture but don't build it until the core is validated.

### Long-term (3-6 months)
7. **Open-source when stable.** The file format is the moat, not the code. Open-sourcing builds adoption. But only after you've dogfooded it enough to know the data model is right.

## The Real Question

**Is this a product or infrastructure?**

If it's a **product**, you need: beautiful UI, magical AI chat, easy onboarding, clear value prop for solo devs and teams.

If it's **infrastructure**, you need: rock-solid data model, great docs, extensibility, integrations, API-first design.

Right now you're building both. That's ambitious but it might be necessary — the infrastructure enables the product, the product proves the infrastructure.

My instinct: **the infrastructure is further along than the product.** The data model and scanner are solid. The UI and chat are not. Focus on making the *experience* match the *architecture*.

## One More Thing

You have 22 ideas captured. That's a lot of surface area. The fact that you're thinking about costs dashboards, background agents, multi-user auth, GitHub Apps... it means you see the full scope. That's good. But it also means you could get lost in possibility space.

**The forcing function is dogfooding.** Use this tool to build Pillar for 2 weeks. Every time you wish it did something, that's the real backlog. Everything else is speculation.

You asked for honest thoughts. Here's the honest part: **this could be really good, but only if you finish the chat agent and solve the self-tracking problem first.** Those two things are existential. Everything else is features.
